results_summary: The study found no significant differences in ankle kinematics among kinesiology taping, athletic taping, and no taping applications on the injured foot. Participants with lateral ankle sprains showed reduced inversion during landing compared to the uninvolved side.
population_specificity: 30 volunteers with a history of unilateral lateral ankle injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of kinesiology taping on lower limb edema, pain, and postoperative mobility in patients following intramedullary nailing for femoral shaft fracture.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in limb volume, pain, or postoperative mobility with kinesiology taping. The only significant improvement was in active knee extension due to enhanced quadriceps force.
population_specificity: 14 patients (7 intervention, 7 control) with femoral shaft fractures treated with intramedullary nailing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Kinesiology Taping (KT) on correcting hammertoe deformities and improving foot loading parameters in a patient with flexible deformities.
results_summary: The study found that KT application led to changes in foot length, maximum foot load, and load under the metatarsals II-III area, suggesting symptomatic improvement for lesser toe deformities.
population_specificity: A female patient with hammertoes and flexible deformities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Kinesiology Taping (KT) on hindfoot position and loading patterns in individuals with hallux valgus and hindfoot valgus.
results_summary: KT significantly improved hindfoot angle and hallux valgus angle while standing and corrected lateral heel loading during gait. The effects persisted after a month of taping, suggesting KT may help normalize foot loading in these patients.
population_specificity: 25 feet with hallux valgus deformity and hindfoot valgus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of kinesiology taping (KT) in improving functional recovery for stroke patients with oropharyngeal dysphagia, comparing it to traditional swallowing therapy (TST) and neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES).
results_summary: The study found that KT, either alone or combined with other therapies, significantly improved swallowing function (measured by multiple scales) at 5 weeks and 3 months post-treatment, with no significant differences between treatment groups. The efficacy of KT was maintained over long-term follow-up.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with oropharyngeal dysphagia (n=37, divided into three treatment groups).
study_duration: Evaluated at pre-treatment, post-treatment (5 weeks), and 3 months after treatment onset.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and treatment fidelity of kinesiology taping (KT) when combined with conservative interventions for shoulder pain through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: Meta-analysis showed large effect sizes for improvements in disability and range of motion (ROM) when KT was added to conservative treatments, but no significant effects on pain. Methodologic quality was reasonably good, but treatment fidelity was lacking in most studies.
population_specificity: Individuals with shoulder pain

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of kinesiology taping (KT) combined with exercise and skin care versus complete decongestive therapy (CDT) on limb circumference, lymphedema volume, grip strength, functional status, and quality of life in patients with unilateral breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL).
results_summary: KT significantly reduced limb volume and circumference at 4 weeks and one-month follow-up, though CDT showed greater reductions at the 4-week mark. No differences were found between KT and CDT in grip strength, functional status, or quality of life outcomes.
population_specificity: 40 patients with unilateral stage 2 breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate and short-term effects of kinesiology taping on the functional capacities of amateur overhead athletes' shoulders compared to other interventions.
results_summary: Kinesiology taping significantly improved shoulder strength and functional performance immediately after and 45 minutes post-treatment, though it was less effective than IASTM for internal rotation improvement. No significant differences were found between kinesiology taping and other interventions for other outcomes.
population_specificity: Eighty amateur overhead athletes (mean age 23.03, weight 78.36 kg, height 1.77 m).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if kinesiology taping improves hallux valgus by affecting foot position and reducing pain.
results_summary: Kinesiology taping significantly reduced the hallux valgus angle immediately after application and after one month of use, and it significantly improved pain perception. Foot length, hindfoot and forefoot surface, and pressure distribution also changed.
population_specificity: Forty feet with hallux valgus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of combining low-level laser (LLL) or high power laser (HPL) with kinesiology taping (KT) on pain, function, and musculoskeletal ultrasound parameters in patients with subacromial impingement syndrome (SAIS).
results_summary: Kinesiology taping alone was effective, but combining it with HPL resulted in better improvements in pain, function, and ultrasound parameters compared to LLL or KT alone. Significant improvements were observed in supraspinatus tendon thickness, echogenicity, and acromiohumoral distance, particularly in the HPL-KT group.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with subacromial impingement syndrome (SAIS).
effective_dosage: Seven treatment sessions (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Treatment duration was seven sessions (exact timeline not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of Kinesiology Taping (KT) on foot loading during gait in patients with hallux valgus.
results_summary: KT significantly improved dynamic foot measurements, including increased load and surface at the first metatarsal head and decreased load around the second to fifth metatarsal heads. The taping also altered foot loading ratios and proportions, suggesting biomechanical benefits.
population_specificity: Forty feet with hallux valgus.
effective_dosage: Not specified (continuous wear for one month).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kinesiology taping (KT) combined with exercise improves pain, functional strength, balance, disability, and quality of life in patients with medial plica syndrome (MPS) compared to exercise alone.
results_summary: KT combined with exercise led to greater improvements in pain intensity, pain threshold, functional strength, dynamic balance, disability scores, and quality of life compared to exercise alone, with statistically significant differences favoring the KT group.
population_specificity: 80 participants with medial plica syndrome (MPS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (KT application details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of Kinesiology Taping on muscle strength, tissue temperature, balance, and mobility in female patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Kinesiology Taping significantly improved muscle strength (extension and flexion) and mobility (TUG test), but had no significant effect on tissue temperature or balance.
population_specificity: 34 female patients (age 60.26 ± 6.51 years) with Kellgren-Lawrence Grade 2 knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (superior Y, inferior Y, and U strip techniques applied).
study_duration: Acute effects assessed 30 minutes after taping.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chiropractic management, including kinesiology taping, could resolve knee pain caused by pelvic imbalance.
results_summary: The patient reported resolution of knee pain after 5 treatments involving kinesiology taping, chiropractic manipulation, and exercises. Pain decreased from 8 to 1 on the Verbal Rating Scale, and muscle strength improved to 5 of 5.
population_specificity: A female patient with anteromedial knee pain and pelvic imbalance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if trunk kinesiology taping (KT) improves trunk function, mobility, and balance in post-stroke patients with hemiparesis.
results_summary: Trunk KT significantly improved TIS scores and directional control of LOS but showed no significant changes in TCT scores, other LOS parameters, FMA-balance, or MRMI scores. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Thirteen individuals with post-stroke hemiplegia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Kinesiology Taping (KT) on cutaneous blood microcirculation in healthy adults compared to rigid taping and no taping.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant increase in cutaneous blood microcirculation with KT under resting conditions. Instead, taping (regardless of elasticity) was associated with immediate reductions in blood flow.
population_specificity: 45 healthy male and female adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of kinesiology taping (KT) and stretching on postural control in young and elderly subjects.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between KT and stretching in improving balance for either age group, though stretching showed a slight improvement in single-leg stance time for elderly subjects.
population_specificity: 40 young subjects (<30 years) and 40 elderly subjects (>60 years).
effective_dosage: Inhibitory tape applied to the gastrocnemius muscle (KT group); 60s of stretch repeated 4 times (stretching group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Kinesiology Taping (KT) on cutaneous somatosensation to noxious and innocuous stimuli in humans with a normally functioning nociceptive system.
results_summary: The study found that taping, regardless of elasticity, may modulate cutaneous mechanosensation, with KT and standard taping showing significant increases in mechanical detection and pain thresholds over time. However, KT, standard taping, and sham taping had similar effects on thermal and deep pressure nociception.
population_specificity: 54 participants with a non-sensitised, normally functioning nociceptive system.
study_duration: Measurements were taken pre-intervention (T1), during-intervention (T2), and during-intervention (T3), but exact duration is not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of kinesiology taping combined with exercise on posture, pain, and functional performance in individuals with subacromial impingement and round shoulder posture.
results_summary: Functional performance improved in both groups, with greater pain reduction correlating to better shoulder function. Moderate correlations were found between posture and functional performance in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Thirty-four subjects with subacromial impingement and round shoulder posture.
effective_dosage: Kinesiology taping applied 2 times per week (with and without tension).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of kinesiology taping on hemiplegic shoulder pain (HSP) in terms of pain intensity, subluxation, muscle activity, and active range of motion.
results_summary: The taping group showed immediate improvements in pain, subluxation, and muscle activity on the first day, and sustained improvements in all measured outcomes after 4 weeks, with significant differences compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Nineteen individuals with hemiplegic shoulder pain after stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of kinesiology taping (KT) on pain, movement restriction, walking speed, daily living activities, and isokinetic muscle performance in female patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: KT showed significant improvements in pain (visual analog scale) and functional capacity (WOMAC scores) compared to sham-KT, though both groups improved in pain and muscle performance. The effects were most notable immediately after treatment and at one-month follow-up.
population_specificity: 61 female patients (aged 50-60 years) with knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grade 2-3).
effective_dosage: KT applied once a week for three weeks.
study_duration: Three weeks of intervention, with follow-ups at one and three months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of truncal kinesiology taping combined with physiotherapy versus physiotherapy alone for improving gross motor function in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Meta-analysis of five RCTs showed that kinesiology taping significantly improved gross motor function in sitting and standing, particularly for children with GMF Classification Scale levels I and II. The evidence supports its use as an adjunct to physiotherapy, though further research on application methods is recommended.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (GMF Classification Scale levels I and II).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Kinesiology Taping on sensorimotor efficiency, balance, and gait in patients undergoing rehabilitation after knee replacement surgery.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in balance, joint position sense, and functional gait performance in the Experimental Group (KT + standard rehabilitation), with greater percentage improvements compared to the Control Group (standard rehabilitation alone). Both groups showed improvements, but KT enhanced outcomes further.
population_specificity: 120 male and female patients (mean age 69 years) after total knee replacement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Kinesiology Taping on pain, breathlessness, and abdominal bloating in a terminal metastatic cancer patient.
results_summary: The patient reported alleviation of pain, breathlessness, abdominal discomfort, and nausea, along with improvements in eating, drinking, energy levels, and physical function after Kinesiology Taping.
population_specificity: A female amateur athlete with terminal metastatic breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of kinesiology taping (KT) with extracorporeal shockwave therapy (ESWT) in improving pain and functional outcomes in patients with plantar fasciitis.
results_summary: Both KT and ESWT significantly improved pain levels, heel tenderness, and functional outcomes in plantar fasciitis patients after five weeks, with no statistically significant differences between the two treatments.
population_specificity: 80 patients diagnosed with plantar fasciitis (7 males, 26 females in KT group; mean age 47.7±9.8 years).
effective_dosage: KT was applied every five days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kinesiology taping, with different application techniques, provided additional benefits to therapeutic exercises in treating congenital muscular torticollis in infants.
results_summary: The study found no significant additive effect of kinesiology taping compared to exercises alone, and different taping techniques resulted in similar clinical outcomes. No significant differences were observed between groups for any outcome variables at follow-up time points.
population_specificity: Infants aged 3-12 months with congenital muscular torticollis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (application techniques described: inhibition on affected side, facilitation on unaffected side).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (assessments at pretreatment, post-treatment, 1 month, and 3 months post-treatment).

study_goal: To assess the impact of Kinesiology Taping (KT) on hemiplegic shoulder pain, upper extremity function, and prevention of shoulder soft tissue injury in subacute stroke patients with hemiplegia during rehabilitation.
results_summary: Therapeutic KT significantly increased pain-free flexion and reduced the occurrence of hemiplegic shoulder pain (HSP) compared to sham KT. However, no significant improvements were observed in upper extremity function, daily activity, or quality of life over sham KT during conventional rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients with hemiplegia (n=44).
effective_dosage: Therapeutic KT applied for 5 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if kinesiology taping reduces pain, swelling, and improves knee range of motion and functional outcomes in the early postoperative phase after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR).
results_summary: Kinesiology taping reduced pain in the early postoperative phase (first to second week) but showed no significant effects on swelling, knee score, or total range of motion. Both groups showed statistically significant improvements in all study parameters over time.
population_specificity: Sixty subjects who underwent elective ACLR with or without concurrent meniscectomy.
effective_dosage: Kinesiology taping applied on the first and second weeks postsurgery, each application lasting 5 days.
study_duration: Two weeks (two applications, each lasting 5 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of kinesiology taping in reducing pain and improving function in a patient with musculoskeletal pain following T8 fracture surgery due to metastasis.
results_summary: The patient reported significant reductions in pain severity, improved control and stability in the left shoulder region, and better overall function and quality of life without any adverse effects.
population_specificity: A 46-year-old woman with musculoskeletal pain following T8 fracture surgery due to secondary breast cancer metastasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and safety of kinesiotaping (KT) compared to compression bandaging or hosiery in managing cancer-related lymphoedema (CRL).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant difference in limb volume reduction between KT and compression, but KT was associated with a higher risk of skin complications (10%-21% of patients). KT was superior to compression in alleviating lymphoedema-related symptoms, though patients receiving bandaging reported higher quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with cancer-related lymphoedema (CRL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of kinesiology taping therapy on pain, function, and joint range of motion in patients with degenerative knee arthritis.
results_summary: The kinesiology taping group showed significant improvements in pain reduction, functional ability, and range of motion compared to the conservative treatment group. These improvements were statistically significant both within and between groups.
population_specificity: 30 patients with degenerative knee arthritis (15 in the kinesiology taping group, 15 in the conservative treatment group).
effective_dosage: Treatment was administered three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the safety and efficacy of Kinesiology Taping (KT) in reducing postoperative chest pain after lung lobectomy.
results_summary: KT was found to be safe with no adverse events reported. It significantly reduced thoracic pain compared to the control group, particularly on postoperative days 5 and 8, and showed lower persistence of chest pain at 30 days.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-85 undergoing lobectomy for lung cancer, excluding those with previous KT exposure, recent trauma, pre-existing chest pain, or intensive care unit treatment >24 hours.
effective_dosage: Standardized tape length, tension, and shape applied over three defined skin areas (chest access site pain trigger point, ipsilateral deltoid/trapezius, lower anterior chest).
study_duration: Tape applied on postoperative day 1, with pain assessments up to day 30.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of kinesiology taping on fibularis longus latency time and postural sway in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that kinesiology taping did not significantly change fibularis longus latency time or postural sway in healthy subjects, with no differences observed between the experimental and control groups.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy young subjects.
effective_dosage: Not specified (application methods described as origin-to-insertion and insertion-to-origin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Kinesiology Taping improves skin blood flow responses in young, elite soccer players.
results_summary: The study found no differences in baseline or thermally stimulated skin blood flow or cutaneous vascular conductance between taped and untaped conditions, suggesting KT did not increase forearm skin blood flow in the tested population.
population_specificity: Thirteen healthy, elite, adolescent male soccer players (age 14.7 ± 0.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Kinesiology Taping (KT) on reducing upper extremity lymphedema in women post-breast cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in lymphedema extent in the KT group (p = 0.0009), while no such reduction was observed in the control group (p = 0.36). KT was concluded to be an effective method for early-stage edema management.
population_specificity: 28 women with grade I secondary lymphedema after axillary lymphadenectomy due to breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of PNF stretching and modified anterior pelvic tilt taping (APTT) on reducing pelvic compensation caused by hamstring shortness during seated double-knee extension.
results_summary: Both PNF stretching and APTT significantly reduced movement distance of the center of gluteal pressure (COGP) and rectus abdominis (RA) muscle activity, but neither intervention significantly affected semitendinosus (SEM) muscle activity. The study suggests APTT may be an effective alternative to PNF stretching for addressing pelvic compensation due to hamstring shortness.
population_specificity: 28 healthy young adult male college students (mean age 21.4 ± 2.1 years) with hamstring shortness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate effects of Kinesiology taping on motor performance (peak torque, hopping distance, joint position sense, and static balance) after muscle fatigue induction.
results_summary: Kinesiology taping significantly increased peak torque and single-leg hopping distance but had no significant effect on active joint position sense or single-leg static balance. The study concluded that Kinesiology taping is effective in restoring muscle power after fatigue.
population_specificity: 45 subjects divided into three groups (Kinesiology taping, placebo taping, and non-taping).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of kinesiology taping on upper-extremity function and activities of daily living in hemiplegia patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in functional independence movements between groups, with taping enhancing both upper-extremity function and daily living activities, though task practice alone showed similar effectiveness.
population_specificity: 30 hemiplegia patients (15 experimental, 15 control).
effective_dosage: Task practice for 30 minutes, 3 times per week (with or without taping).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Kinesiology Taping (KT) could reduce lymphoedema and improve manual dexterity in women post-breast cancer treatment, and if it could replace traditional multilayered bandaging.
results_summary: The study found that KT was not effective in reducing lymphoedema II and III(0) in women after breast cancer treatment and could not replace traditional multilayered bandaging. No significant improvements were observed in limb size, grip strength, or range of motion after 4 weeks of therapy.
population_specificity: Women who had undergone breast cancer treatment and developed upper extremity lymphoedema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the influence of Kinesiology Taping on lymphoedema reduction in women after mastectomy.
results_summary: The study found a 55% reduction in lymphoedema volume in the study group using the own taping method, compared to 27% in the control group using traditional taping. Kinesiology Taping also improved upper limb joint mobility and grip strength.
population_specificity: 44 women who underwent single mastectomy with lymph node removal.
effective_dosage: Tapes were applied three times every 7 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Kinesiology Taping on lumbar spine mobility and subjective pain intensity in patients with lumbar spine pain.
results_summary: The study found that Kinesiology Taping increased lumbar spine mobility in flexion and reduced pain intensity, as measured by the Schober test and VAS scale, respectively.
population_specificity: 100 patients (89 women and 11 men) with lumbar spine pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Kinesiology Taping improves hand functioning and muscle strength in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The study found that Kinesiology Taping significantly increased hand muscle strength (p<0.05) compared to standard physiotherapy alone, with strength gains correlating with improved hand function test performance (r>0.8).
population_specificity: 20 patients (16 women, 4 men) with rheumatoid arthritis, average age 62.2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Kinesiology Taping versus standard lymphatic drainage in reducing postoperative edema in patients undergoing limb lengthening via the Ilizarov method.
results_summary: Kinesiology Taping produced a statistically more significant reduction in thigh and crus circumference compared to standard lymphatic drainage, indicating faster and more effective edema reduction. Both treatments significantly reduced edema, but Kinesiology Taping was superior.
population_specificity: 24 patients (mean age 21 years) undergoing lower limb lengthening via the Ilizarov method with postoperative edema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Kinesiology Taping (KT) for treating breast cancer-related lymphedema compared to quasi KT and multilayered compression therapy.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in edema reduction between KT and quasi KT, and multilayered bandages performed much better than taping methods. KT was deemed ineffective for secondary lymphedema after breast cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Sixty-five women with unilateral stage II and III breast cancer-related lymphedema.
effective_dosage: K-tapes, quasi K-tapes, or multilayered short-stretch bandages applied every treatment session, 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of shoulder kinesiology taping versus sham taping in improving outcomes for stroke patients with shoulder subluxation when combined with standard physical therapy.
results_summary: The study found that both kinesiology taping and sham taping groups showed significant improvements in shoulder subluxation distance, active range of motion, pain, disability, and functional independence, but the kinesiology taping group demonstrated more effective changes than the sham group.
population_specificity: 35 stroke patients with shoulder subluxation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved taping application alongside standard rehabilitation exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immediate effects of thoracolumbar fascia kinesiology taping on fascia tone/stiffness, low back pain, and standing balance in individuals with transfemoral amputation.
results_summary: Kinesiology taping significantly reduced pain more than sham taping and improved anterior-posterior and medio-lateral sway in standing balance, particularly with eyes closed. Both groups showed pain reduction, but the experimental group had a higher rate of improvement.
population_specificity: Syrian male participants with transfemoral amputation (n=29).
effective_dosage: Not specified (application method described, but dosage not quantified).
study_duration: Immediate effects measured at baseline, post-6MWT, and 30 minutes post-taping.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate effect of kinesiology taping (KT) on muscular imbalance in the lateral flexors of the neck in infants with congenital muscular torticollis.
results_summary: KT significantly improved Muscle Function Scale (MFS) scores on the affected side and increased scores on the unaffected side in infants with torticollis, but had no effect on healthy infants. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Twenty-nine infants with congenital muscular torticollis and muscular imbalance in the lateral flexors of the neck, plus 5 healthy infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects (benefits and harms) of splinting, including comparisons with kinesiology taping, for people with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: The study found low-certainty evidence that splinting may provide little or no short-term symptom improvement and uncertain long-term effects. Kinesiology taping showed no additional benefits compared to splinting, with low-certainty evidence.
population_specificity: Adults with CTS (mean ages 42-60 years, symptom duration 7 weeks to 5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of suprahyoid muscle strengthening exercise using kinesiology taping (KT) on muscle activation and thickness in community-dwelling elderly.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant increases in suprahyoid muscle activation (mean and peak) and muscle thickness (digastric and mylohyoid) compared to the placebo group, suggesting KT may be effective for dysphagia rehabilitation in healthy older adults.
population_specificity: 24 healthy older adults (community-dwelling elderly).
effective_dosage: Resistive swallowing exercise 10 times a day (50 swallows per day) with KT applied at 70-80% tension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of kinesiology taping on upper limb function in stroke patients and summarize the main outcomes from analyzed studies.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain intensity, shoulder subluxation, general disability, upper extremity function, and range of motion (PROM) of flexion in stroke patients using kinesiology taping compared to control groups.
population_specificity: Patients with stroke (hemiplegia, hemiparesis, or related upper limb impairments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kinesiology taping, as an adjunct to botulinum toxin injections, improves symptoms and quality of life in cervical dystonia patients.
results_summary: Kinesiology taping did not significantly improve dystonia severity compared to botulinum toxin alone, but it did enhance quality of life. No differences were found between kinesiology taping and sham taping in symptom improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with cervical dystonia (25 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Kinesiology Taping (KT) for shin splints through a systematic review of existing evidence.
results_summary: The review found mixed results on KT's efficacy for shin splints, with some studies reporting positive effects but methodological quality ranging from poor to moderate. Current evidence supporting its effectiveness is limited.
population_specificity: Individuals with shin splints (total sample size of 141 participants across four studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of kinesiology taping on lumbar proprioception, pain, and functional disability in individuals with nonspecific chronic low back pain.
results_summary: Kinesiology taping reduced pain and disability scores after 3 days with large effect sizes, outperforming placebo taping. However, it did not significantly improve lumbar proprioception compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Thirty individuals with nonspecific chronic low back pain.
effective_dosage: KT applied with 15-25% tension for 72 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of kinesiology taping (KT) with different tension levels on pain, physical function, and other outcomes in people with knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found that KT application with tension was not superior to application without tension for pain, physical function, range of motion, or muscle strength. Evidence for edema, balance, and quality of life was limited, and current evidence does not support KT use in knee OA.
population_specificity: People with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether kinesiology taping (KT) could enhance the activation of suprahyoid muscles during swallowing, potentially aiding dysphagia rehabilitation.
results_summary: Both 50% and 80% stretch KT significantly increased suprahyoid muscle activation, required effort, and resistance during swallowing compared to no KT, with 80% stretch showing greater effects than 50%. The study suggests KT has therapeutic potential for dysphagia rehabilitation.
population_specificity: 23 healthy adults
study_duration: Single session (measured during five saliva swallows per condition)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Kinesiology Taping (KT) provided faster symptom improvement, enhanced pain-free range of motion, and increased acromiohumeral distance compared to exercise-based treatment alone in individuals with rotator cuff-related shoulder pain.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the KT and control groups in symptoms, functional limitations, range of motion, or acromiohumeral distance at mid- and long-term follow-ups, indicating KT did not provide superior outcomes over exercise-based treatment alone.
population_specificity: 52 individuals with rotator cuff-related shoulder pain (RCRSP).
effective_dosage: Not specified (KT was added to the treatment but details on application frequency or method were not provided).
study_duration: 6 weeks (with follow-ups at 3 weeks, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immediate effects of kinesiology taping on scapular reposition accuracy, kinematics, and muscle activation in individuals with shoulder impingement syndrome.
results_summary: Kinesiology taping significantly reduced reposition errors in scapular protraction and improved scapular kinematics during arm elevation, but had similar effects on muscle activation as placebo taping.
population_specificity: Thirty overhead athletes with shoulder impingement syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the presentation of shoulder pain, motor impairment, range of motion, and alignment in hemiplegic shoulders following acute stroke, as part of a pilot trial on kinesiology taping.
results_summary: The study found that pain and reduced passive range of motion were present in a small number of participants despite severe upper limb motor impairment. Shoulder subluxation and scapula malalignment were common, but the clinical course of shoulder pain and range of motion post-stroke remains unclear.
population_specificity: Patients with acute stroke and severe upper limb motor impairment.
study_duration: From 24 hours post-stroke until discharge, with measurements every three days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of kinesiology taping as an adjunct therapy for musculoskeletal pain, particularly in conditions like plantar fascia pain, pes anserine bursitis, and low back pain.
results_summary: Kinesiology taping was found to improve symptoms for patients with plantar fascia pain, pes anserine bursitis, and low back pain, though the evidence supporting its use is not of high quality. The modality is considered relatively safe but should not replace active physical therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with musculoskeletal pain, including plantar fascia pain, pes anserine bursitis, and low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of therapeutic Kinesiology Taping (KT) added to a rehabilitation program in reducing pain and disabilities in individuals with Rotator Cuff Tendinopathy (RCTe), as well as its effects on shoulder control factors like muscular activity, acromiohumeral distance, and range of motion.
results_summary: The study will evaluate KT's mid-term and long-term effects when combined with a rehabilitation program, measuring outcomes at baseline, 3 weeks, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 6 months. Results are pending dissemination, but the study design suggests a rigorous assessment of KT's added benefits.
population_specificity: Individuals with Rotator Cuff Tendinopathy (RCTe).
study_duration: 6-week rehabilitation program with follow-ups at 12 weeks and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of Kinesio Taping (KT) on chronic low back pain (CLBP) by analyzing randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Moderate evidence suggests KT is no more effective than conventional physical therapy for pain and disability, but may improve range of motion and motor control short-term. Limited evidence shows KT is superior to sham taping for some outcomes.
population_specificity: 306 subjects with chronic low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of facilitatory and inhibitory kinesiology taping on the tone of the pectoralis major muscle in healthy individuals.
results_summary: Facilitatory taping significantly enhanced muscle activity and showed a negative correlation with contralateral pectoralis major length, suggesting effects beyond the direct application site. Inhibitory taping did not produce significant results.
population_specificity: 24 healthy volunteers without relevant pathologies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological effects of andrographolide (from King of Bitters) on stress-induced thermoregulatory and physiological responses in mice.
results_summary: Andrographolide demonstrated dose-dependent adaptogenic properties, effectively reducing stress-induced hyperthermia and body weight changes, comparable to diazepam. It also potentiated pentobarbital hypnosis, suggesting diazepam-like desensitization of stress responses.
population_specificity: Male and female mice.
effective_dosage: 3 mg/kg/d, 10 mg/kg/d, and 30 mg/kg/d (oral administration, once daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory and anti-allergic potential of seven phytoconstituents isolated from Andrographis paniculata (King of Bitters) by assessing their effects on key inflammatory and allergic mediators.
results_summary: The study found that several phytoconstituents, particularly andrographolide, isoandrographolide, 7-O-methylwogonin, and skullcapflavone-I, significantly inhibited the production of inflammatory mediators (NO, PGE(2), IL-1 beta, IL-6, TXB(2)) and allergic mediators (LTB(4), histamine) in cell-based assays.
population_specificity: In vitro studies using J774A.1 macrophages, HL-60 promyelocytic cells, and RBL-2H3 basophilic cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of sensory stimulation interventions, including light therapy, on persons with dementia, focusing on outcomes like alertness, agitation, and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found that sensory stimulation interventions, including light therapy, had significant effects on reducing negative behaviors in persons with dementia, though methodological limitations were noted. Only a few studies assessed quality of life and well-being, with mixed results.
population_specificity: Persons with dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bright light exposure increases [(18)F]-FDG uptake in the olfactory bulb and hippocampus, potentially indicating neurogenesis.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in [(18)F]-FDG uptake in both right and left olfactory bulbs after 5-day bright light exposure, with the right olfactory bulb remaining significant after adjusting for illuminance. This suggests a possible link between bright light exposure and neurogenesis.
population_specificity: 55 participants in a university hospital setting.
effective_dosage: Bright light exposure + environmental light (specific intensity not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review literature on the effects of photobiomodulation (PBM) on mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) to understand its role in tissue regeneration.
results_summary: The review found that PBM positively affects MSCs, enhancing cell function, proliferation, and migration, with effective doses ranging from 0.7-4 J/cm². The combination of stem cell therapy and laser therapy improved treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) in vitro or in tissue regeneration contexts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms, dosimetry, and safety of photobiomodulation (PBM) and explore its potential applications in managing side-effects of (chemo)radiation therapy in head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: PBM shows promise in managing complications like ulceration, inflammation, and pain, but its impact on tumor behavior remains unclear due to conflicting in vitro results and insufficient clinical data. While no adverse tumor outcomes were reported, further research is needed to confirm PBM's neutrality in cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing radiotherapy for head and neck cancer (HNC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the role of Light Therapy (LT) in treating bipolar depression, either as monotherapy or in combination with total sleep deprivation (TSD), by synthesizing existing evidence through a meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that LT significantly decreased disease severity in bipolar depression, both with and without TSD, and with concomitant medication. Augmentation with LT was more effective than treatment without LT, though the optimal intensity and frequency of LT remain unclear.
population_specificity: 489 patients with bipolar depression across nine studies.
interactions: Concomitant medication was mentioned, but no specific interactions detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of bright light therapy (BLT) in treating nonseasonal depression.
results_summary: BLT showed a significant reduction in depressive symptoms, particularly when administered for 2-5 weeks and as monotherapy, but results were insignificant for perinatal depression. The overall heterogeneity of trials was moderate, and long-term effects were not explored.
population_specificity: Individuals with nonseasonal depression, including subgroups like perinatal depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of laser and light therapy as treatments for acne vulgaris compared to traditional topical and systemic therapies.
results_summary: The study found that laser and light therapies are effective for treating acne by targeting Propionibacterium acnes porphyrins, acting as anti-inflammatory mediators, and reducing sebaceous gland activity. These therapies have minimal side effects and are safe during pregnancy, with at-home devices also showing efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with acne vulgaris.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of photobiomodulation (PBM) in managing various side effects of chemoradiation therapy in head and neck cancer patients, including oral mucositis, and to suggest optimal PBM parameters for these applications.
results_summary: PBM showed potential in managing a broad range of side effects, with optimal parameters identified for oral mucositis (e.g., wavelength 633-685 nm or 780-830 nm, energy density 10-150 mW, dose 2-3 J/cm²). The study also proposed parameters for other complications like dermatitis and dysphagia, suggesting PBM could enhance supportive care in head and neck cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing radiotherapy or chemoradiation therapy for head and neck cancer.
effective_dosage: Wavelength: 633-685 nm or 780-830 nm; energy density: 10-150 mW; dose: 2-3 J/cm² (max 6 J/cm²); frequency: 2-3 times weekly to daily.
study_duration: Not specified (treatment schedule varied from twice weekly to daily).
